dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter Mitty (30s) sits at his small kitchen table, balan his check book. We see his last several expense entries:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom's new apt. deposit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O's braces (2nd installment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Piano delivery to Mom's new apt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In-piano humidity control system

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the morning rush hour, a crowd of businessmen wait the corner to cross the street. Walter is among them, dre in a short-sleeve business shirt and tie and with a brief on hand. Nothing happens. Then Walter's head explodes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up toward the clouds, propelled skyward, were the content (ideas and images) of Walter's head; they've begun to flo toward the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some office work is going on. Then past the window (outsi comes floating down, in slow motion, Juan Valdez the Colombian Coffee guy (his donkey's floating down way in t distance).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This happens outside other high-rise and professional building windows - a floating Bishop Desmond Tutu, the silver Monopoly piece Top Hat, Statler and Waldorf (the t elderly curmudgeons from The Muppet Show) and additional detritus from Walter's mind such as Manute Bol, The Beast Boys, etc. CREDITS PLAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter sits at a Midtown Starbucks. He's got his laptop o and he's in the middle of a phone call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, you didn't really provide much detail about your occupation. Most people put theirs on their eHarmony page. You don't care to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that like a must? Can't I just say like "I'm employed" or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like okay but that's not a great idea) Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My work's not really that interesting. To women. Um. Or men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a Practical Asset Manager. For a corporation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sounds like he agrees it's not interesting) ....okay. What do you do when you're not working?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mostly I guess I commute to work? It's like an hour and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. No worries. I'll submit this information, then check back in the afternoon for your possible eHarmony matchups. That's exciting, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is, Todd. Yeah. Hey, when can I leave a "wink" for someone? To see if they "wink" back, or..?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's looking at his laptop. On screen is the eHarmony dating page for CHERYL M. (34), pretty but she looks like sort of pretty girl who takes the bus; text beside her ph reads "Leave a wink for Cheryl M. to indicate your interest..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have your eHarmony profile all uploaded in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So like in two minutes. But hey, you're a little light, if you don't mind me saying this, in your "Been There, Done that" column.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Part of the eHarmony client profile has a section Been Th Done That - where people list their accomplishments, trav etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I forgot what I put there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should beef that up. If you can think of anything to add that would make it, you know, not blank.... give me a ring, I'll add it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sure will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like he's a little

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Are you okay, man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doesn't know the guy, surprised he asked) ...Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sound, I don't know, a little stressed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinks its odd this guy's taking a personal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I just had some stuff on my mind. The past couple months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ....What kind of stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still thinking this personal interest is a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just, you know... life stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I get that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some awkward moments pass as Walter's unsure about follow through on heavy conversation with a stranger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...okay thanks for asking, I guess, um, Todd was your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Todd Mahar. I'll be your eHarmony counselor, while you're with us here at eHarmony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Hey, let's hope you'll have a special lady on your mind later today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds good, Todd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later... Todd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They finish their call. Walter looks at the computer pict of Cheryl M., then out the window at actual Cheryl M. (CH MELHOFF, 34) crossing the street just outside the window the Time-Life building lobby. Then as Walter stands to go outside the Starbucks window, a grand piano (exploded fro Walter's head) falls from the sky onto the middle of the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's out on 6th among a crowd waiting for a light to cross. Then a black and white New Orleans Jazz Funeral procession passes in front of him - black and white in th sense everyone in it and all their instruments and lively waving umbrellas are in black and white. Walter and the business people around them are in color. CREDITS END. Th title appears: The Secret Life of Walter Mitty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter crosses the expansive lobby and passes a colleague on his way to the building elevators.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up, Roy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. We just got acquired. Our company. This morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our whole company did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter wasn't expecting this; it's thrown him some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's in an elevator with two other guys in suits. He addresses the first one (GARY MANNHEIM)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary? You're Vice President of Acquisitions. Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... we just got acquired. Did you know that? Roy said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The company that I'm supposed to be acquiring companies for? It just got acquired?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Roy said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, that's not promising for me probably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, they probably have their own acquiring guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's probably the guy who acquired us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. That was me. Ted Hendricks. Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the second man in a suit (TED HENDRICKS) who's be with them all the while. They all shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted Hendricks. Vice President of Acquisitions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary Mannheim. Um. Vice President of Acquisitions. Too. So what are you going to be doing at the company, Ted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Managing the acquisition. Identifying overlap. Reducing staff where we find redundancy. What's your focus been here, Gary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I've been managing acquisitions. Identifying overlap. Then reducing staff where I find redundancy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Further awkward moments pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow, okay. That's not...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's not good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a Practical Asset Manager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you play an important role here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. Yeah. Totally. I work in a one-on-one basis (on a one-on-one basis I mean) with all our photographers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted just looks at him for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I was really getting into this song. What were you saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter listens to the elevator muzak Ted just referred to It's like Maneater in muzak; no one could get into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just saying I manage our film negatives from the moment they arri-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting to leave) Let's talk later. We have a specific time set aside to conference with employees of the former company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure. But it's not at this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to see the board and start evaluations now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Thank you. (flustered, feeling that was a dumb thing to say) I mean "not thank you." I mean like "looking forward to it" I should have said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted just looks over. The door's closing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through the closing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking forward to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors are almost closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll come by sometime this week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awesome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going to come by my...um?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors close. Ted's not coming by Gary's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter walks up a long hallway toward his department floo on the walls are hugely blown up Life Magazine photograph Twelve foot high Muhammad Ali, Morgan Freeman (Oscar pose Moon Landings. - Walter looks small compared. The last ph he passes is familiar - a black and white of a New Orlean Jazz Funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The division Walter works in has fifty employees seated around an open floor plan - fifty cubicles in view. Walte arrived at his to find on his desk a wrapped gift with a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heard rumbling's Life's over. Wanted to give you somethin cool if this is the last photo batch. Hope when you open and look inside you'll think it's pretty special.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's unwrapped the gift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a leather wallet. Its front is embossed with the inscription from S.O. to Walter Mitty - thanks for the gr work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter looks back at the letter; it finishes - by the way neg 12 is my best ever. Landmark. The Absolute Quintessen of Life. .... the rest of the batch kind of sucks. Sean

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter has been working through a Life photo order negati box - it's marked Sean O'Connell. There's a co-worker (HERNANDO) cleaning up in the distance. Walter has been examining a negative roll with his loupes (magnifiers wor eye glasses). THEN HE NOTICES SOMETHING THAT STOPS HIM. T negative roll, where the 12th negative should be, has bee cut; 12 is missing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Hernando-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This 12th neg? From this last Life roll?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it of?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's of something that's the Absolute Quintessence of Life. Or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's "quintessence?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means like the best ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment goes by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you can't find it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. That's not going to go over well with the new asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The storage room is separated from the greater division f by a wide glass window wall. At that moment, Walter has noticed new supervisor Ted Hendricks on the other side of glass. He's holding a conversation with a LIFE EDITOR the Walter can hear it (muffled).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the issue shaping up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got an email from Sean O'Connell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The photographer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. He said he got the cover shot. His best. The Quintessence of Life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does Quintessence mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like the best ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Awesome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted starts to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (repeating to himself for

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quintessence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This has Walter concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cafeteria is a large white room, with massive black a white Life photographs serving essentially as wallpaper. Particularly, they are images of physical and human immen (photographs of the summitting of K2 and the beachheads o Normandy) and make the office workers here (Life magazine low-level corporate workers among whom Walter is one) see tiny in terms of their personal accomplishments but also physically. Walter and a co-worker TIM NAUGHTON sit in fr of the Massive K2 mountain summit photograph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim, did you find out anything about Negative Box 2-6? Where it was sent from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like he's a real big

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the Sean O'Connell commission?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, the guy who took this--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter gestures to the K2. It's taken from above a guy wh just summitted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing in shipping. The box just showed up it seems like. There's no receipt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'm getting nervous with these new guys around. Lost negative. But I'm not going to freak out. I think my work here the last nine years speaks for itself. I've made my mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then new superior Ted Hendricks walks past, accompanied b Life's EXECUTIVE ADMINISTRATORS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who am I evaluating next?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding an employee file labeled W. Mitty) W. Mitty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the black guy from Accounts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...He's not black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. He's just a white guy. With a mustache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't have a mustache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course he doesn't have a mustache. He's a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've walked past Walter and out of the cafeteria - but Walter's heard every word - not promising.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter sits at the cement bench on 6th just out front of Time-Life building. He's looking at a photograph he's tak from his briefcase. It's a bad print - the kind someone t before their camera's set - over exposed, out of focus - impossible to discern the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheryl Mellhoff sits down beside Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands her the foggy print - it's clear they have an established working friendship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's either a man with one sideburn. Or a candelabra. Or a Happy Days lunch box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (can't make it out clearly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's... is it two badminton racquets? What's it supposed to be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the Quintessence of Life. So I don't think it's two badminton racquets. Sean O'Connell took this just before he took another one we lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like that's significant) You lost a Sean O'Connell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at the out of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'm trying to figure out what this picture is. I think he focused, set his lens then took the missing picture. It's just a better picture of this. What is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe Sean has it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The negative? Yeah, I tried to reach him. He's always in Bahrain. Or a shanty town or somewhere - I got one email off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter shows Cheryl an email exchange from Sean O'Connell

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It reads - in need of info for neg 12 of neg roll three, 2-6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean's reply - Best picture I've taken. The total F'ing Quintessence of Life. I hope you're as happy with it as I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's reply = Cool, but can't find it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean's reply - Out of Office. This is an auto reply. Sean O'Connell will be out of the office through the month of November.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No cell phone. He's out on a freelance. I'd really like to find him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter has taken further photographs from his briefcase

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are pictures from the last roll he sent in. I'm trying to draw a bead on his location by analyzing these.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you figured anything out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet. Because my trail is... water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter starts showing Cheryl the photographs. The first o which is water - just a picture of water, could be an oce lake, or pool (puddle).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Starbucks, which I don't know which one. (flipping to the next one) And a man (or woman's) thumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a picture of a thumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been trying to figure out the gender (of the thumb), as I sat here. How many people in the world?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six billion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone's got two, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two, too, what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thumbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. But I think there are more Starbucks, so I don't know if that's what you'd call a hot trail--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look what Sean gave me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter has taken the gift wallet out - S.O. to Walter Mit thanks for the great work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because we covered, you know, so many hotspots together the last 9 years... (a little more quietly) ...boldly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (having some fun with

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys covered the hotspots together boldly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a team. Yeah. By Sean actually going to the hotspots, and by me staying here waiting for the pictures of hotspots to come back so I can boldly transfer them to magazine format.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheryl's laughed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What did you do this weekend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're moving my mom here. I went and packed her house up. What about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son and I went on a bike ride in Lake Valhalla. Jersey. We brought lunch. Had lunch in an actual field, of grass. We went swimming. My friend Marny lives on the lake. (getting to what's on everyone's minds around

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...This is going to be the last issue. Life's going to be strictly online after this merger. No new photographs. We're just going to be an internet photo storehouse. That's what I'm hearing. They're going to let most of us go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter sits there for awhile. That's tough news. He's got lot on his mind. Then he gets a text: From Odessa, it rea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - piano a-holes want 300 more dollars to take the piano b come down. I have to go. Like right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's running through the huge Time-Life lobby for the 50th St. glass exit doors, but outside the lobby it's not York right now. It's Sana'a, Yemen. And running parallel Walter, along the window glass wall beside him, is rugged photographer SEAN O'CONNELL, loaded with camera gear. Wal runs out the building entrance and is now running side by side with Sean in Sana'a, Yemen in the midst of an anti- American rally, making a desperate dash together out of t under a volley of middle-eastern shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's with all these shoes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angry Middle-easterners are throwing their shoes at Walte and Sean as they sprint by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a sign of disdain here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a lot of shoes, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've been targeting western journalists all summer. It's been a real hot August.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for doing all the field work here and risking your ass and getting hit by shoes and stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just get this camera bag out of here. We can shoot the shit later, O'Connell. Over whiskeys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are in Sana'a, Yemen, but they're chasing an actual metro south. Walter has finally reached its doors, though he's continuously struck by shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's slightly out of breath. He's caught the bus. It' just New York again. Walter walks up the crowded bus aisl and finds a seat. Some time passes. Walter looks out the window, his daydream has faded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little later, Walter's got his lap top out, trying to l a "wink" for Cheryl M. (Cheryl Mellhoff) on eHarmony . It doesn't work: unable to perform request. Walter looks at it's not the smooth next step he was expecting. He tries again. Same result.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's in the midst of a phone call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to leave a "wink." For someone. But it didn't work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they're not required to respond to you favorably. We can't

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it says "unable to perform request," Todd. So I don't think my wink really went through. Do I have like a broken page or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Broken page? I've never heard of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, okay, something's not working. On my page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, let me look here

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, we received your application breaking your personality into 29 different dimensions, and, okay, I see the problem. You don't have any.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dimensions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Further time passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I don't have any dimensions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that we can determine. Through our models. You're just lacking distinguishing features as our system sees it. Based on our really extensive evaluation, you seem, to us, a little too indistinguishable from everybody else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pretty long time passes as Walter wrestles with this consideration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not standing out. In a way that would allow anyone to actually notice you. So hey, let's enhance your profile. Let me ask you, did you always want to be a practical asset manager?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to be one now. I just am one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an occupation. When I became an adult I thought that would be possibly a good thing to have. Because I keep getting bills from places.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are some of your accomplishments?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I studied music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April? One April?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. But I was working at Orange Julius to save money for college. That April. And my hands were always sore from working the Frother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you play any pieces?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A piece of Cheers. The first piece. Part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if we should list that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter gets a text from Odessa that says I'm leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Todd. I have to go. I have a piano situation I have to take care of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um hey, can I have my four hundred dollars back?

dialogues.text: A little while later, the pilot's in the pilot's chair of helicopter. The blades are spinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's about to lift off out of Nuuk. Walter's in the dista standing thirty yards away near the pub, looking over. He not going. Then the helicopter starts to lift at the same moment Walter has a change of heart and starts to run tow it to come along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The helicopter begins to ascend (the environment around t pub is pretty, different than what we've seen). We also haven't seen Walter sprinting before, which he is now (briefcase), arriving, then leaping three feet up into th passenger seat of the helicopter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's high above Greenland, flying over a fjord. It's breathtaking. He yells to be heard from the passenger sea the pilot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a fjord?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen pictures of fjords. But I've never actually seen a fjord. I don't think I've ever even said the word fjord out loud--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop saying fjord. It's annoying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a look from way up at an international shipping vessel mid-sea. The weather around it's getting rocky. On deck, they're prepping a life raft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's getting rocked a little in the helicopter passen seat. The weather's getting rough. They're in some low ly storm clouds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling over the blades) We're not going to be able to land on the freighter. I've got to drop the radio parts and you in a life raft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a short drop, but your decision. You can just fly back with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling over the blades) I'd really like to get my hands on this property. They're making some changes at the office. It's going to reflect poorly on my work. I might get let go. And I have a mounting piano situation that's-- (rocked big time) Whoa...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pilot carries on to the freighter. Walter seems to be calling on his reserves to see this through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's noisy. The weather's rough. There is lots of lifting dropping. Walter's steadying himself in the cargo hold, preparing to jump..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're doing great. We're only six feet up. Just jump out the door, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is wide view of what's going on. We see the back of hovering helicopter. To its left is the international shipping vessel the Dolores which has placed a life raft between it and the helicopter. There is still some space the right of the frame where there's open water. That's t side of the helicopter Walter mistakenly jumped from. Aft he surfaces, he starts to drift away from the freighter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's treading water a fair distance from the freighte The crew (Chilean) has gathered at the bow of the freight The captain calls out to Walter through a megaphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're sending a pontoon. Try to remain calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this point a fin passes behind Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through the megaphone) Okay, if that's a porpoise--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sort of to himself,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If what's a-- (noticing the fin) what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that is a porpoise, befriend it. Porpoises are mammals with rare intelligence and sympathy. They often protect swimmers from predators.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fin circles by again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that's a shark, strike it. Their snouts are sensory hubs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you-- I just see a fin. Can you get a bead on some more information?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On board the crew has a brief consultation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (then, to Walter through

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're confident that's a shark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fin comes nearer. Walter steels himself. Then he find some presence of mind and power and is able to deter the thing away by thrashing at it with a few decent punches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a moment) Okay, now we think that was a porpoise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After another moments, another fin shows up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That probably is a shark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this point, though, the pontoon arrives and Walter scrambles into it (he still has his briefcase).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter has dried off. He's being tended to by some young Chilean sailors. He's been sounding them out about where O'Connell is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean O'Connell? He was picked up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From your ship?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pilot boat came. They took him. Four hours ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Took him where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's dawned on Walter that he's missed Sean. Just by a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we radio them? There's something I need to discuss with--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You jumped into the ocean with our radio components. No. We are, as you say, "on our own."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The freighter's hauling automobiles. The surface of the s looks like a mall parking lot. One of the Chilean sailors accompanies Walter on a walk among the car rows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can sleep where Sean did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop alongside a Subaru. The Sailor opens the driver door. He means this is where Sean slept. In this Subaru. Walter's confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean slept here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In this Subaru Outback?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. That's where our undocumented laborers sleep. Our Stevedores. He was photographing our workers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was photographing Chilean Stevedores?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (about the Outback) This was his room/car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now it will be your room/car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter has gotten in. There are five Chilean Stevedores i the back in different states of rest - sleeping, reading, playing chess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you guys, were you living in this car back seat when Sean O'Connell lived in the front seat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter starts miming taking photographs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: La Quintasencia....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy's pointing to where Walter is in the front seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: La Quintasencia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that-- Are you saying quin--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: La Quintasencia...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you saying Quintessence? In the Spanish form? Yeah. Sean says that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A deck Squall Alarm sounds. These guys leave the car quic (to perhaps batten something down). Walter notices the breaktime snack they were enjoying - half's been left beh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that Clementine cake? My mom makes-- I didn't know anyone else made that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's alone in the Subaru.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clementine cake. Wow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches for some cake, it's been sliced into pieces, wrapped bakery style in some stray paper from the backsea Walter takes one such slice. While the storm lifts and lo the ship, Walter enjoys some clementine cake, then he not something about the paper scrap it's wrapped in. There's handwriting on it. Walter examines it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What Walter's holding is a half-torn page bearing cursive handwriting. There is a date beside the word: Eyjafjallajkull. Then TTL shoemount flash. Zoom bounce flash. Nikon Camera....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Sean's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a later destination and date on the paper - and scrawl beside it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...this is an itinerary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this storm, Walter has climbed up the crow's nest ladder and stands in the crow's nest with the English- Speaking Chilean Sailor who escorted him to the Subaru. Walter's showing him the paper - Eyjafjallajkull

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where Sean is. Tomorrow. This gibberish. I have to crack it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to crack the gibberish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to crack anything. It's a volcano. In Iceland. That's the name. Eyjafjallajkull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Sean's in Iceland. We're going past there, right? Can we land there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can get you there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you get me there tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can get you there tomorrow, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like some Clementine cake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's brought the cake up with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very good. It tastes, man, exactly like my mom's. I didn't know Chilean mom's made this. Small world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thank you. I have to actually perform a function up here, during the storm. That's why I'm up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to monitor the mooring winches and wind Lasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're standing, I'm sorry, like right where I'm supposed to be looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'm going to go, take my cake and.....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter starts to descend the crow's nest ladder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The storm has broken. The sea is calm. The sun is out. Th is a huge ship. Walter's sitting on the bow, all by himse His briefcase is beside him. It's quiet. He's looking out the water, then (oddly) his cell phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Todd Mahar. From eHarmony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Oh. Hey. (like it's weird to be getting a call out here from Todd Mahar) Um, do I owe you guys money? Because your supervisor was clear I can't get my 400 dollars back. But I don't think I'm going to renew-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I just wanted to see how you were doing. You didn't sound great last time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last time we talked? The time you told me I have no personality?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you know, you just left your application so empty. Share something about yourself. It doesn't have to be major league.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life's full of small accomplishments. What do you strive to do everyday, that you take pride in? Can I ask you that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I take my work seriously. Also keeping a tidy apartment. I help my sister out paying her bills now and then. But can we not list that? None of that stuff really seems like an accomplishment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know there's a way to consider it where the tasks you accomplish (paying some of your sister's rent--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Braces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hasn't asked me for rent money. For like a year. But I did pay for her braces. She's 36.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, taking care of yourself and your household, your mom, after you do that without ever failing, for a long time, hey that becomes an accomplishment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some time passes. A bird flies by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I fought a dolphin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't they supposed to be nice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are. I think they're probably the best mammal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (meaning like aren't we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're mammals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter doesn't say anything about us being the best. Life heavy for him right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This mammal tried to protect me. And most of the other mammals I know, like the mammals at the office, they're dicks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you near dolphins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on a ship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near Greenland. I tracked a thumb here. To Nuuk, Greenland. I located the thumb. Now I'm fortunately going to Iceland to correct an oversight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm going to tweak your profile, add "sailing" or whatever to your Done Thats. I'll put Swims with Dolphins, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was just one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can really put Swims with Dolphin. That sounds like you have a pet dolphin you swim with everyday. Can I handle this please? It's my job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Todd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sound a little better?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I? Because I think I'm a little worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's been equipped with a kayak pole and life vest. S of the crew assist him down a ladder to the ocean; others keep watch over a kayak waiting there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a mile and half to Iceland. It's as far in as we can get with our hull size.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. Okay. I'm supposed to kayak in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reykjavik is due north. You'll be there by 9 am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's quietly kayaking through an empty expanse of the Atlantic. His paddle makes noise; that's it. Then Cheryl Mellhoff emerges from underwater - but she's giant. She t up the whole horizon. She's catching her breath like she' been underwater for a while. Then her son Rich (giant) po up from underwater beside her. He catches his breath, too but he's pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stayed under longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just barely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's do it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. One, two, three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheryl fakes going underwater on three. Rich has. She's s above water. She's cheating. She stays there for a while, smiling. Then Rich pops up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're cheating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay. One two three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both get caught faking it this time, and they start laugh. Then they both go underwater. They're under for a time. A pretty long time, in fact. Then Cheryl surfaces. Rich doesn't. She's breathing again, but she expected to Rich and doesn't, and now she's concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rich...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rich?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, he pops up. But he's coughing, was under too lon and has taken in some water; he's scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. Come here. Hey come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hugs him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, it's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's freaked, he's crying a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, don't worry. You're good. Don't worry. Hey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a moment, she begins to sing to distract him. She's singing Bob Marley's Three Little Birds pretty well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, about a thing, `cause every little thing, is gonna be all right. Don't worry. About a thing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter looks on from (from his kayak). He's worried about lot of things, but what he's picturing soothes him too. T day dream fades. Walter keeps kayaking. It looks desolate then a guy in a rubber triathlon swimsuit swims by. Then another one does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ....shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wide shot shows that Walter has kayaked near to the coa of Reykjavik, Iceland during the swimming portion of a triathlon. Now he's in the midst of a hundred pissed guys rubber swim suits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's in the heart of Reykjavik, Iceland, driven throu the city. He's taking in the sights, looking around throu the cab window, when his phone rings again. He checks his caller I.D

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm just making some yogurt. With some banana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It snowed today. Didn't expect that. Not much. Just a light little cover. Very pretty. Less than an inch even.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's awesome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My piano got towed, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment goes by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Your piano got towed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Odessa said it wasn't there. Where you said it was going to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She said possibly that it got towed. That that's not her space anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lent her money for that space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you, honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Iceland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's out front of the capital building in Reykjavik texting Odessa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter writes - Wtf on mom's p.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waits. This comes back - I had to go last minute to yo workshop out of town. Can you handle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter sends - Can you please take care of this - I am in Iceland. I repeat. Iceland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets back - thanks lots :) I'll have my phone off forseeably. Love, O.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter just sits there for a while - tending to the piano has been left to him - at this critical moment. He turns around. You can see the volcano (where Sean O'Connell is) looming way in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter has left. He's taken off. He's looking out the sma window, down at Iceland as he goes, down at Eyjafjallaj the volcano he nearly reached. It's getting smaller. Walt watches as it does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home now, Walter lands at JFK. He's in economy, taking ou his laptop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is now safe to turn on portable electronic devices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's laptop is on. So he goes on eHarmony. Again, he tries to leave a wink for Cheryl. The reply he gets, agai is "unable to perform request."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's two a.m. Walter is alone on a terminal moving walkwa He hasn't changed since we met him - he's still got hold his briefcase. He's looking (again) at the out of focus picture. He can't draw anything out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter hurries through a car impound facility. Among the of impounded cars, there is his mom's grand piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Walter's turn in line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Retrieving..?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mom's piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Make and color?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doesn't really understand the question in regard to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a Baldwin? Um, Walnut, I guess? A Walnut Baldwin. Piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment goes by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's right out there. I just walked by it. Do you have more than one piano?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impound fees. I'm making your fees. Heavy duty tow fee. $370. Two nights overnight. $80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Failure to display city vehicle inspection sticker. $112.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy just keeps adding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a car. Its a musical instrument. I should have had my musical instrument inspected? By a government.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy ignores Walter. He just stays at his task which i adding money Walter doesn't have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter looks on while movers consider how to load his mom piano into the back of their moving van.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we taking it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't move into my mom's until tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what do you want me to do? Drive really slowly? We can store it at our warehouse and move it in the morning. But that's two moves. Separate billings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man.... You know what? (meaning they can leave without the piano) Don't worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter walks over, lowers himself beneath the keyboard, f a grip, then rises and lifts the piano up by himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's carrying the piano on his back, walking down the middle of the New Jersey Turnpike, slowing down traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter climbs a set of stairs to the subway with the pian his back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter sits on a bench waiting for the train. The Grand P is beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter has brought the piano onto the subway. Then the su hits one of those mid-tunnel stops where the train stops, the lights go on and off. When the lights return we see t piano's gone. Walter's still there though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Piano move (third) - $1,100.00

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is an empty (small) apartment. Walter and his sister ODESSA sit on the carpet. She's pretty, good spirit, a li flighty (also she's wearing braces). She's watching Walte write this piano moving check. But she's looking at a checkbook entry a few entries above it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does that say eHarmony? Four hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little amused) Are you on eHarmony?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why did you give them four hundred dollars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to join, but-- I don't really even want to be on it. I'm just trying to do this thing with someone at work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (meaning do what) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this point we see a piano float up into view outside t living room window beyond them, odd because they're fifte stories up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to do that Pia Colada thing? (singing pretty well) "If you like Pia Coladas, and getting caught in the rain while wearing a cape--"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not how it goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the guy answers a personal ad and finds out it's his wife. They have a good laugh, then they make love on the cape while drinking Pia Coladas or something, and wearing capes, I think. Anyway. I'm hoping she'll click my profile and not realize that she works in my office area. Then we can realize it and have a good laugh. Then--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make love on a cape? While wearing capes? Because that's not what they do in the song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, then we can know that we picked each other out, you know, from the whole planet. Not just the cafeteria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's quiet for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... We're friends. I'd like there to be more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was hoping this web site (that they won't let me be on) would show her more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter is putting his checkbook back in his briefcase. Od has noticed the out-of-focus photo Walter carries in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (about the picture) What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. What do you think it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Odessa looks the photo for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark Chatham?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young desk clerk picks up the house phone. A ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a Man Man's here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk listens for a moment. Walter waits to see if he be allowed up. He will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Room Seven Ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter waits just outside a Four Season's hotel room door He's just finished knocking. The guy who holds conglomera Mark Chatham answers the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Man, I'm sorry. I was hoping I could talk to you for two secs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment goes by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Walter Mitty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a black woman, with a mustache. I'm a man who used to work for your company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your the guy from TV? I'm a Man Guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I was in jail. We didn't get TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know which way Chatham's going to go. But he respects Walter. He extends his hand. Walter takes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I just talk to you for two secs.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not in my room. Because you're freaking me out a little. Can we maybe sit out here. Indian style or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark and Walter sit Indian Style facing each other in the Four Seasons fifth floor hallway. Chatham's holding a negative roll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was one absent from the roll. But I have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter hands the small envelope over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the one Sean O'Connell wants for the cover? The Quintessence one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. For the last issue. That's the complete roll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was in the briefcase? Out on the street, when you were getting cracked in the neck by police sticks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (meaning the roll) Those.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That last one's pretty late. Nine days late. There was an unforeseen set of unbelievable shit that happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do people think that you're a black woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sit way in the back. Maybe that's-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does tear gas really feel like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a pretty intense burn. It's like having Cajun eyes. Spicy eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw you on TV fighting a mailbox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long time passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was that a question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not like in the form that I just said it. But...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter still doesn't say anything about his participation a riot. So Mark rephrases it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why were you fighting a mailbox?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I was revved up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From fighting with a piano for a month and trying to get someone at my company to evaluate my position there based on understanding what I actually do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fight pianos, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not in the way that I fought the mailbox, but just in the way that I've been struggling with one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (recounting Walter having told him this moments

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You rode in a car on a boat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You slept on a copier in a business center?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're an interesting guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleased to hear this) Someone else told me that. An hour ago. Hey, I don't want to take up too much more of your time. But I'd like my severance. There's no cause to keep it from me. That's what I was trying to tell you downtown. I did my job well for nine years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all you were trying to say downtown?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some moments go by next, while Mark and Walter sit Indian style with the Sean O'Connell photo of Walter sitting bet them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to run some numbers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark has stood up and started in to his hotel room. Walte been following him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (meaning don't follow me

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not right now. I don't even know where the numbers are. There in some guy's computer. Show up Monday, let's see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door closes, Walter's left out there to wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter has returned to Brooklyn; he's heading up a set of Subway stairs up to a neighborhood street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter crosses the huge lobby, dressed as always for work

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter has entered the elevator. He's alone. It won't wor without his floor elevator key (which stopped working onc was let go). Walter waits a moment. Then he tries his key The button illuminates. Walter starts to ascend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter has reached the floor elevator corridor door to hi division floor office. He's just tried his pass key. That functions as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter waits in a line at an accounting office window cou (like a DMV) behind recently let-go colleagues Tim Naught and Gary Mannheim. Tim speaks to the accounting clerk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim Naughton? Severance package?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands Tim his check. He's sad, but he takes it and he off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary Mannheim. Same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a moment, Gary gets his severance. He's also blue a it. Then Walter steps up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter Mitty? Is there a... possibly there's a severance package for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts typing into her keyboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was fired for cause, but then I think I maybe gave them cause to provide me with a severance package.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not really a package. It's just one check. For forty two hundred dollars. That's what everybody's getting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Possibly there's that? For me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's typed additional stuff. Then she roots around in a check stash. Then she hands Walter an envelope. He takes He looks at it for a while. For the first time in a long while, he seems relieved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's just walking through the park. He looks at peace There are many others around, all coming and going at a normal pace, but the earth around them transforms from wi to summer smoothly over the course of thirty seconds as t naturally inhabit the park in their regular ways. So when Walter sits at a bench. It's all midsummer around him. He smiling from relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a grand piano mid-air in Manhattan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a winch machine, a huge rig, lifting this piano t the 7th floor of the residential building Walter secured his mom. Walter and Odessa stand in Battery Park, looking at the piano. The movers are setting it into the removed window space. It looks like it's going to fit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The piano has fit easily here. Odessa and Edna are straightening up, putting the last few things away. The room's in good shape. It's really pretty nice. Edna seems home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, babe, come on. We'll go grab lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Odessa and Edna head out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go. The room is quiet. Walter looks around again. Ma it happen took considerable effort no one but Walter will know about. After a moment, he goes and sits at the piano Some time passes. Then Walter plays the beginning of Chee Then he gets up and follows his sister and mom out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's walking with Odessa and Edna. They've come past newsstand with magazine displays. Walter was going to wal right on by like Edna and Odessa did. But he's noticed something on the magazine racks that's stopped him. He st there for a while looking at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the last issue of Life Magazine. Its cover is a blac and white photograph of Walter siting on a cement bench o front of the Time-Life building. He's got his lunch in a brown bag beside him; he's looking over photo prints with loupe, working carefully on some day in the past to fulfi the wishes of Life's photographers- a person who's work t world never knew took place. It's really good. You can se the word LIFE on the building sign above the bench. So th last photograph, on the last cover of Life, elegantly hon the people who quietly worked there and cared for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter stands in front of the newsstand looking at it. It the first time he's seeing it. It's a message that to Sea at least, and possibly to others his work was meaningful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On another day, Walter's sitting in Battery Park across t little street where his mom lives. He's with Cheryl. Her Rich skateboards around the park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd the move go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody's good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's Life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The company or the... thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The company's okay. The thing's tough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you glad you're not there anymore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm excited. About the new stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the new stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know yet. Would you have lunch with me? Somewhere not in the cafeteria. For once. Out somewhere? In the world. I was wondering that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles at Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts looking in her scheduler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ninth? Is that good? Two days?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ninth. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter seems pleased. Rich skates by and does a move. Che and Walter sit there a while. They can hear piano music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that your mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some time goes by. Walter looks tired, worn out from his extended journey and his large efforts to keep the lid on critical matters of his life. But he also looks relieved satisfied. Piano music continues. The title appears again The Secret Life of Walter Mitty. Then CREDITS BEGIN.
